questions.text: Tetanic contraction is due to the accumulation of _______ ions.
questions.solution:
Tetanic contraction occurs due to progressive accumulation of Ca2+ ions with rapidly repeated stimulation of skeletal muscle.

  • With rapidly repeated stimulation, activation of the contractile mechanism occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred, and the individual contractions fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called a tetanus (tetanic contraction).
  • A single action potential releases sufficient Ca2+ to cause a twitch contraction.
  • However, the duration of this contraction is very short because Ca2+ is very rapidly pumped back into the SR.
  • If the muscle is stimulated a second time before the muscle is fully relaxed, there is progressive accumulation of Ca2+ and the force of contraction increases. Thus, twitch forces are amplified as stimulus frequency increases.
  • At a high level of stimulation, intracellular Ca2+ increases and is maintained throughout the period of stimulation, and the amount of force developed greatly exceeds that seen during a twitch. The response is termed tetany.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles, as seen in the biopsy.

Image: Vacuolar myopathy in McArdle's disease

Features:

  • Poor exercise tolerance
  • Abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%)
  • Very low blood lactate after exercise

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the detection of hemosiderin deposits?
questions.solution:
Perl's Prussian blue stain is used to detect Hemosiderin deposits.

Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived granular pigment that is golden yellow to brown. It accumulates in the tissues when there is a local or systemic excess of iron.

Iron is normally stored within cells in association with the protein apoferritin, forming ferritin micelles. Large aggregates of these micelles are hemosiderin deposits seen both in light and electron microscopy. 

Image 1: Hemosiderin deposits in tissue

Image 2: Prussian Blue Staining of hemosiderin

Note:

  • Iron dispersed in the cytoplasm is seen in electron microscopy as ferritin micelles.

questions.text: A diabetic patient diagnosed with Covid 19 infection on steroid therapy presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose and redness of the right eye. There is significant visual impairment. On examination, there is a blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. 

Invasive Mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia/uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids/ immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

MUCORMYCOSIS:

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of rhizopus, mucor, and lichtheimia. Among them, the most prevalent species are Rhizopus oryzae and R. delemar. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. They invade tissues of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels particularly paranasal sinuses and orbit. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis- They can be stained with 10% potassium hydroxide and can be cultured.

On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.

Under the microscope, they appear as nonseptate, irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

The below image shows broad aseptate and irregularly branched hyphae seen in mucormycosis

Treatment: Surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration (1st line agent). Other antifungal agents used are isavuconazole and posaconazole.

Amphotericin B:

This is available in 3 forms

  • Amphotericin B deoxycholate- It is inexpensive but is highly toxic and has poor nervous system penetration
  • Liposomal amphotericin B- It has better nervous system penetration, better outcome than amphotericin B deoxycholate. It is very expensive.
  • Amphotericin B lipid complex- It is less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B deoxycholate but expensive.

Important side effects are:

  • Infusion-related toxicity- fever, chills, muscle spasms, vomiting, headache, and hypotension.
  • Nephrotoxicity- It is seen in nearly all patients treated with amphotericin B.
  • Liver damage
  • Seizures and arachnoiditis may develop after intrathecal therapy.

 

Other forms:

  • Pulmonary mucormycosis- It is the second commonest form and presents with fever, dyspnea, cough, and chest pain.
  • Cutaneous mucormycosis- It usually results after trauma or any penetrating injury to the skin. The infection can penetrate into fascia, muscle, and bone.
  • Gastrointestinal mucormycosis- It primarily occurs in premature neonates who have disseminated disease or necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • Disseminated mucormycosis- The infection from the primary site can disseminate to the brain, bones, mediastinum, etc.

questions.text: An ECG revealed the following finding. Which of the following drugs would be most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
This ECG with a wide QRS complex with prolonged QT interval points towards the diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Sotalol is most likely to cause Torsades de pointes.

Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points)-It is a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.

Acute management - Magnesium and Isoproterenol

Chronic management - Beta blockade and cardiac pacing

questions.text: The venom of a pit viper is:
questions.solution:
Vipers are vasculotoxic. 

The venom causes enzymatic destruction of cell walls and coagulation disorders.

The main site of action are endothelial cells of blood vessels. There is hemolysis of red blood cells as well.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding serous otitis media?

choices.text: Adenoid hypertrophy is the most common cause in children causing bilateral serous otitis media
Tumors of nasopharynx is most common cause in adults causing unilateral serous otitis media

questions.solution:
All the given statements are true.

Serous otitis media: 

The fluid is nearly sterile and the causes are :

Malfunctioning of eustachian tube:

  • Adenoid hyperplasia in children.
  • Benign and malignant tumors of nasopharynx. This cause should always be excluded in unilateral serous otitis media in an adult.

Other causes include

  • Interference with ET opening like in cleft lip and cleft palate and enlarged tonsils
  • Otitic barotrauma
  • Increased middle ear secretions like in an allergy.
  • Persistent effusion of ASOM due to inadequate treatment dose or duration

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below ?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis from the above image is pterygium. 

Pterygium:

It is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.

It is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue.

It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory. 

It is made up of three parts:

  • a "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge),
  • a head,
  • a body.

Occurs due to exposure to radiation: UV-B.

The most common site is nasal.

Clinical features:

  • Astigmatism with the rule, usually
  • Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge.
  • Fuchs islets are small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, often present at the advancing edge.

Treatment: Excision

To prevent recurrence:

Mitomycin C or 5 fluorouracil

  • Auto-grafting: Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is the best method.
  • Bare sclera technique has high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%.
  • PERFECT surgery (Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant) has zero rate of recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting property of bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorous acid.

Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it. When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

HOCl → H + OCl

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid. It is 70-80 times more effective than Hypochlorite ion.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for large scale purification of water and for drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • Alongside its anti-pathogenic attributes, it oxidizes iron, manganese and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odor producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • Action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    • Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water which contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorines.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors caused due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorines separately.

questions.text: A patient comes with a ​history of clean-cut injury which is not lacerated. He says that he received his last dose of tetanus vaccination about 10 years ago. What should be given next?
questions.solution:
A single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the wound is clean and the last dose was received more than 10 years ago.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

  1. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.
  2. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.
  3. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.
  4. Unknown or never taken immunization
Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes all of the following symptoms except:
questions.solution:
The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms:

Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.

questions.text: A  45-year old male presents with bilateral flank pain, gross hematuria. He has a family history of autosomal polycystic kidney disease. How many cysts should be present in the kidneys to diagnose him with ADPKD?

choices.text: At least 2 cysts in each kidney
At least 3 cysts in each kidney
At least 4 cysts in each kidney
Even a single cyst in each kidney

questions.solution:
2 cysts in each kidney should be present to make the diagnosis of ADPKD.

Since the genetic analysis is not known here but has a family history , diagnosis of ADPKD based on USG findings is generally made using the unified criteria by Pei et al in 2009:

Age (in years) Imaging findings
15 - 39  Total of ≥3 cysts, unilateral or bilateral
40 - 59 ≥2 cysts in each kidney
 

The age of the person is 45 and hence 2 cysts should be present in the kidney to make the diagnosis of ADPKD.

If the genetic analysis is known, then ultrasonographic diagnostic criteria for ADPKD1 is based on Ravine criteria:

  • At least 2 cysts in 1 kidney or 1 cyst in each kidney in an at-risk patient less than 30 years
  • At least 2 cysts in each kidney in an at-risk patient aged 30-59 years
  • At least 4 cysts in each kidney for an at-risk patient aged 60 years or older
 
 Adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)

Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with a mutation in the genes PKD1 (chromosome 16p, produces a protein called polycystin1) and PKD2 (chromosome 4q, polycystin 2).

ADPKD

  • Autosomal dominant trait 
  • Mutations in PKD1 and PKD2, which, respectively, code for polycystin-1 (PC1) and polycystin-2 (PC2). It is
  • Characterized by the progressive bilateral formation of renal cysts.
  • Many patients are asymptomatic until the fourth to fifth decade of life.
  • Kidney stones with more than half of the stones  composed of uric acid.
  • Intracranial aneurysm (ICA) occurs four to five times more frequently in ADPKD patients.

Clinical features: The disease does not usually manifest before the age of 30 years, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed.

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Irregular upper quadrant mass
  • Loin pain
  • Hematuria
  • Infection
  • Uremia

 Extrarenal cysts in ADPKD:

  • Hepatic cysts
  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Seminal vesicle cysts
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts

ADPKD is an important cause of renal failure, affecting 10-15% of the patients who receive haemodialysis.

In autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease(ADPKD), cysts are least likely to be present in the lungs.

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.solution:
The Brown–Sequard syndrome presents with contralateral loss of pain sensation.

Lateral hemisection of the spinal cord produces the Brown–Séquard syndrome.

Clinical features

  • Ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract involvement) 
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column involvement)
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract involvement) one or two levels below the lesion
  • Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of a deep tendon reflex

questions.text: Which is not true regarding the given image?

choices.text: Circular ring in the proximal esophagus

questions.solution:
The given image shows Schatzki’s ring which is a circular ring seen in the distal esophagus.

  • It is usually present at the squamocolumnar junction.
  • The cause is obscure but it is strongly associated with reflux disease.
  • It may be associated with dysphagia and respond to dilatation along with medical anti-reflux therapy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of serous discharge from an external opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. What is the location of the internal opening?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is diagnostic of Fistula-in-ano with external opening at 8’O clock position which implies that the external opening of the fistula is lying posterior to the midline.

According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline (6’O clock position). Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at 6’O clock position.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

questions.text: The image shows plain CT of a patient with head injury. The diagnosis is ____.
questions.solution:
The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with mass effect.

Extradural hematoma (EDH)

  • EDH is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery (pterion is the thinnest part of the skull and overlies middle meningeal artery).
  • The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.
  • Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis. Sometimes, herniation may be associated with a false localising ipsilateral hemiparesis, known as the Kernohan-Woltman notch phenomenon, in which the free edge of the tentorium compresses the contralateral crus cerebri in the midbrain.

questions.text: After a surgery, the surgeon asked the intern to remove the Foley's catheter but he/she could not do it. The surgeon himself tried to remove it but he was unsuccessful as well. What should be the next step of action?

choices.text: CT-guided rupture of bulb of Foley's
Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
Inject water to overdistend the balloon until it bursts and Foley's can be removed
Use ultrasound guidance to locate and prick the balloon after inflating with 20ml water

questions.solution:
The best technique in this situation is ultrasound-guided rupture of the balloon percutaneously after inflating it with 20ml water. It is important subsequently to cystoscope the patient to ensure that any fragments are removed before they can form a foreign body calculus.

A retained Foley catheter is usually caused by blockage of the channel that connects the balloon to the side arm. Cutting off the side arm and attempting to clear the channel with a wire is only occasionally successful.

questions.text: Placenta accreta means:

choices.text: Villi penetrate through myometrium to the serosa

questions.solution:
Placenta accreta is when the villi are attached to the myometrium.

Placenta accreta syndromes describe the abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. The abnormally firm adherence to the myometrium is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.  

Nitabuch layer-A layer of fibrin between the  compact endometrium and the cytotrophoblastic shell in the placenta.This layer is absent in placenta accreta.

Types

Definition

Placenta accreta  

Villi are attached to the myometrium.

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium. 

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

These three variants are encountered in an approximate ratio of 80:15:5, respectively.

questions.text: You are working as a Junior Resident in the department of pathology. You receive a specimen from Gynecology OT following resection of a lateral adnexal mass. You see the following marked structures on light microscopy. This is a distinct feature of which cell?
questions.solution:
The formation of Call-Exner bodies is a distinct feature of granulosa cells.

The mature graffian follicle is spheroidal or ovoid in shape and contains pent-up secretion, the liquor folliculi. The lining consists of two layers: (i) Theca interna and (ii) Granulosa layer.

Within the theca interna layer lies the granulosa cell layer, which consists of cells that have a characteristic appearance. The cells are 8–10 μ in diameter. The nuclei always stain deeply and the cells contain relatively little cytoplasm.

Scattered amongst the granulosa cells, particularly in the vicinity of the discus proligerus, are small spherical globules around which the granulosa cells are arranged radially. These structures form Call-Exner bodies. These are pathognomic for granulosa cell tumors. They are distinguished by their "coffee bean" nuclei.

In one area, the granulosa cells are collected together to form a projection into the cavity of the graffian follicle called the discus proligerus or cumulus oophorus.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The  X-ray reveals an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius and there is dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint, which is diagnostic of Galeazzi fracture-dislocation.

The patient with Galeazzi fracture-dislocation presents with pain, swelling and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On clinical examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke’s pouch and arises near the pituitary stalk, commonly extending into the suprasellar cistern.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually presenting the suprasellar region arising near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to mass effect. They can be clinically aggresive due to their tendency to recur. Adamantinomatous (children) and Papillary (adult) are two variants of craniopharyngioma. Calcification is characteristic of the adamantinomatous variety (found in childhood). Wet keratin nodules are the characteristic histologic feature of adamantinomatous type.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol rich, thick brownish yellow fluid that is compared to "machine oil".

  • Patients usually come to attention due to a headache and visual changes including decreased acuity or visual field abnormalities (bitemporal hemianopia).
  • These children also have endocrinologic abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction and GH deficiency. 
  • There can be evidence of mental retardation also. 
  • They are minimally invasive, adhere to adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf normal brain structures
  • CT may show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic wall components.
  • MRI:
    • Cysts
      • T1: iso- to hyperintense to brain (due to high protein content "machinery oil cysts")
      • T2:Mostly hyperintense
    • Solid component
      • T1 C+ (Gd): vivid enhancement
      • T2: variable or mixed 

Usually treated by trans-sphenoidal or trans-cranial resection followed by adjuvant radiation therapy. 

Other options:

Option B: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region. Microadenomas are best shown on contrast-enhanced images. Marcoadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance

Option C: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with amnesia. Which of the following will not be impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Name of pet bird growing up

questions.solution:
The ability to drive a bicycle will not be impaired in this patient with amnesia.

The ability to drive a bicycle is a non-declarative memory and non-declarative memory is preserved in amnesia.

Non-declarative memory includes:

  • Skill learning
  • Habit learning
  • Simple forms of conditioning

Declarative memory supports the conscious recollection of facts and events.

  • Memory for routes, lists, faces, melodies, objects
  • Memory for other verbal and nonverbal material

Memory of the melody of his favourite song, name of pet bird growing up and route navigation are all types of declarative memory.This is impaired in amnesia.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who underwent surgery for appendicitis was given a high dose of opioids postoperatively to relieve the pain. But within few hours,  a fall in SpO2 and respiratory rate were noted. Which of the following drugs has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid-induced respiratory depression and Naloxone has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient.

Opioid-induced respiratory depression is mediated by the action on µ receptors (µ2) in the brainstem respiratory centers. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist, which can reverse the respiratory depression induced by opioids.

Respiratory depression can be prolonged when opioids are taken with other CNS depressant substances like alcohol, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, inhalational anesthetics, and other sedative-hypnotics.

However, droperidol, scopolamine, and clonidine do not enhance the respiratory depressant effects of fentanyl or other opioids.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: A short-acting opioid antagonist with a duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborn due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: A Long-acting opioid antagonist with a with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: A Long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: A young girl comes to the opd with complaints of nodules on her hair shafts as seen in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows irregular white nodules along the hair shafts suggestive of white piedra.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:

  • White piedra: It is characterized by the presence of soft, white or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.
  • Black piedra: It is characterized by the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. It affects the scalp hair most often. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.

It is usually asymptomatic. Management involves cutting off the affected hair and usage of topical antifungals.

questions.text: The clinical application of the effect shown below is -
questions.solution:
The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. It is easily controlled and delivers its maximum dose at a precise depth and can go as far as 32 cm. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak. The behavior of the proton can be precisely determined and the beam can be directed so the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumor site. Immediately after this burst of energy, the proton completely stops to irradiate and the particles come to rest. 

Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.
